title: Wine & Dine Wisconsin offers tour of Milwaukee's food scene
text:
A guide to sounding like a pro when you sample beer | Oct. 5, 2015 
To experience the best of the Milwaukee food scene, you could resolve to eat and drink your way around the city over the next year. ...Or, you could simply attend Wine & Dine Wisconsin this weekend. 
In one afternoon on Saturday or Sunday, you can sample the fare of many of those same restaurants, as well as other local food producers, sip a wide array of wines, beers and spirits, take in cooking demonstrations from local chefs (even do some cooking yourself) and generally have a glass-clinking good time. 
With more than 170 exhibitors at the annual tasting event, produced by the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel and presented by Boston Store, there will be plenty for attendees to check out during the show, which runs noon to 5 p.m. both days. 
Here are some highlights from this year's event at the Wisconsin Center, 400 W. Wisconsin Ave.: 
Critic's Choice: This special food sampling opportunity brings together 17 restaurants from dining critic Carol Deptolla's Top 30 lists, including 12 from this year. Note: It's only on Saturday, and it costs extra. 
Figure skating: On Sunday, watch local skaters perform on a Skate America rink, and check out a cooking demonstration by Olympic medalist Brian Boitano, who also will sign copies of his cookbook. 
New brew: Samples of a special brew by Milwaukee Brewing Co. — cleverly named EditoriAle — will be passed out at the Journal Sentinel booth at the front of the exhibition hall, where you also can meet some of your favorite writers. 
Get crafty: On the back side of that booth, make a wine cork key chain for yourself or as a stocking stuffer. 
Get cooking: Milwaukee Area Technical College again will offer hands-on classes. Make a pumpkin tart, Asian spring roll or Spanish tapas — or decorate cupcakes. 
But also check out the many other cooking demonstrations on three stages. 
Love sushi? Demonstrations by the folks from Rice N Roll Bistro will be held at 11:30 a.m. and 12:30, 1:30, 2:30 and 3:30 p.m. both days at "Sushi Square." 
Eat up! Among new restaurants offering samples on the main exhibit floor are the Big Eazy, with Cajun food; two additional Marcus restaurants: Safe House and Miller Time Pub & Grill; and the Nepalese restaurant The Cheel. Eat cheese to your Dairyland heart's content at two cheese islands. 
Swirl and sip: Try your choice of 26 wine brands in the Pick 'n Save Wine Gallery, along with other wines throughout the floor. 
Cheers! Or order a craft cocktail from the Bittercube Bar. 
Help the hungry: Feeding America Eastern Wisconsin will hold a fundraising raffle both days for items donated by exhibitors and sponsors. Their volunteers will be staffing the glass washing station, with tips also going to fight hunger. 
Book a one-of-a-kind cruise: Justin Aprahamian, chef-owner of Sanford Restaurant, and former Sanford chef-owner Sandy D'Amato will be on stage at Wine & Dine. Next August, the James Beard Award winners will team up for a first-ever Wine & Dine Wisconsin European river cruise. Learn about the weeklong AmaWaterways cruise at Wine & Dine and sign up there for a $500 discount. If you go 
Where: Wisconsin Center, 400 W. Wisconsin Ave. 
When: Saturday and Sunday 
Hours: Main floor: Noon to 5 p.m. (opens at 11 a.m. for JS Insiders). Critic's Choice: noon to 3 p.m., Saturday only. 
Cost: Saturday — $50 in advance, $60 at the door. Saturday with Critic's Choice — $85 in advance, $90 at the door. 
Sunday — $40 in advance, $50 at the door. 
Advance tickets can be purchased online up to midnight on Friday or at select Pick 'n Save stores. Critic's Choice tickets are available only at wineanddinewisconsin.com . 
Who: Only adults 21 and older can attend Wine & Dine. © 2015 , Journal Sentinel Inc. All rights reserved. About Nancy Stohs
